claim: If video recordings of lectures are provided, nothing in particular happens to class attendance.

supporting.text: Studies have shown that providing video recordings of lectures does not significantly impact attendance, as many students still prefer the interactive experience of attending in person.

attacks.text: Studies have shown that providing video recordings of lectures does not significantly impact attendance, as many students still prefer the interactive experience of attending in person.
Some studies indicate that lecture recordings can reduce attendance, particularly among students who prioritize convenience over interaction.
The reduction in attendance due to recordings is often temporary, as students eventually realize the value of in-person interaction for learning.
Lecture recordings may disproportionately affect attendance in large classes where personal interaction is minimal, undermining the original argument.
Even in large classes, recordings can enhance learning by allowing students to review material, which may compensate for any attendance drop.

supporting.text: Research indicates that when lecture recordings are available, some students skip classes, assuming they can catch up later, which can lead to lower attendance rates.

attacks.text: Research indicates that when lecture recordings are available, some students skip classes, assuming they can catch up later, which can lead to lower attendance rates.
Studies show that while some students skip classes, others use recordings as a supplement, leading to no significant net change in attendance.
The availability of recordings may disproportionately affect attendance in large lectures compared to smaller, interactive classes.
Even in large lectures, mandatory attendance policies or graded in-class activities can neutralize the impact of recordings on attendance.

supporting.text: Institutions that provide lecture recordings often report no substantial change in attendance, as students value the immediate feedback and engagement opportunities of live lectures.

attacks.text: Institutions that provide lecture recordings often report no substantial change in attendance, as students value the immediate feedback and engagement opportunities of live lectures.
Studies have shown that attendance drops by 10-20% when lecture recordings are provided, as students prioritize convenience over engagement.
The drop in attendance is often temporary, as students eventually realize the value of live interaction and return to attending lectures.
Lecture recordings can lead to a false sense of security, causing students to skip lectures and fall behind due to procrastination.
Procrastination is more related to individual student habits rather than the availability of lecture recordings.
Institutions reporting no change in attendance may have a biased sample, as they might only survey engaged students who attend lectures regardless.
Many institutions use randomized surveys to ensure unbiased data collection, making the reported attendance trends reliable.

supporting.text: Data from universities with lecture recording systems show a decline in attendance for certain courses, particularly those with large enrollments, where students feel less accountable for showing up.

attacks.text: Data from universities with lecture recording systems show a decline in attendance for certain courses, particularly those with large enrollments, where students feel less accountable for showing up.
Studies indicate that attendance decline is not universal and depends on factors like course difficulty and instructor engagement, not just recording availability.
In some cases, recorded lectures improve attendance by allowing students to review material and engage more effectively in subsequent classes.
The decline in attendance may be offset by increased online engagement metrics, such as views and participation in digital forums.

supporting.text: Many students use video recordings as a supplement rather than a replacement for attending lectures, leading to no net effect on overall attendance numbers.

attacks.text: Many students use video recordings as a supplement rather than a replacement for attending lectures, leading to no net effect on overall attendance numbers.
Studies show that when video recordings are available, a significant portion of students skip lectures, reducing overall attendance.
The studies cited in B1 may not account for students who attend more lectures due to better understanding from supplementary video use.
In courses with difficult material, students rely more on video recordings as replacements, leading to lower attendance.
Even in difficult courses, many students attend lectures for real-time interaction and clarification, offsetting any drop in attendance.

supporting.text: Surveys reveal that a subset of students admits to attending fewer lectures when recordings are available, especially if the course material is perceived as easy to learn independently.

attacks.text: Surveys reveal that a subset of students admits to attending fewer lectures when recordings are available, especially if the course material is perceived as easy to learn independently.
Surveys may suffer from self-reporting bias, as students might overstate or understate their actual behavior.
Studies show that self-reported data in educational settings often aligns with observed behavior when cross-verified with attendance records.
The subset of students who reduce attendance may be offset by others who attend more consistently due to the safety net of recordings.
Empirical data from universities shows no significant net change in average attendance when recordings are introduced.
